Hi Tamia! My name is Niranjana and I am one of the teaching assistants for this course! I have provided some more explanations for questions two and three from the Kinetics: Rate of Chemical Reactions practice problems. After 15 seconds, four red products are formed and only two green products are formed. This means that the red product forms twice as quickly as the green product. Another way of saying that is the rate of change of the red product is twice as fast, or twice the magnitude, of the rate of change of the green product. For question 3, to solve this problem, you have to determine the amount of reactant you had initially and subtract it from the amount of reactant you have after the reaction has gone on for 15 seconds. To find the rate of change you divide the difference in the concentration between the final and initial states and divide by the time that the reaction has been taking place. The reason the rate of change is negative is because as a reaction occurs, the reactant becomes used to form the products and consequently\xA0 decreases over time\xA0 If you look at the diagram at the beginning of the practice problems, this is also represented visually as you see that the number of blue circles gets smaller from the initial state to 15 seconds and continues to decrease at 30 seconds and so on.\xA0

Hi Peter, my name is Niranjana and I am a teaching assistant for this course. My apologies for the delay in responding to your questions. I have provided responses to your questions below. (1) No, as another student posted as well the equilibrium constant does not have units. The ratio that you use to determine the equilibrium constant is either entirely in units of concentration or pressure, in which case the units cancel once you divide the values. In the type of example that you described where there are an unequal number of reactants and products in a reaction, and therefore in the equilibrium constant expression, the activities help cancel the units so the overall equilibrium constant expression, k, is unit less. Typically, activities are negligible and will not be considered in general chemistry. Activities simply help correct for the dissociation of reactants and products, but you do not need to worry about them for this course. (2) The value of Keq for this reaction is 6.54 × 10−3 at 25 degrees Celsius. (3) Yes, this is correct. When you reverse a reaction, the value of the equilibrium constant will be equal to 1/(Keq for the forward reaction). (4) Although we want to think that any changes to the reaction conditions will change the value of Keq, this is not the case. For example, changes in pressure alter which side of the reaction is favored at equilibrium, but it does not change the value of Keq itself - only changes in temperature will alter the value of Keq. I hope this helps clear up your questions. Also, remember that if you have coefficients in front of your reactants and products, you must raise the concentration or pressure of those reactants to that power when you are calculating the equilibrium constant value. This rule applies to this reaction for example, where the reaction is N2O4 --> 2NO2. So you would divide ([NO2]^2)/(N2O4). Also, be sure to exclude any reactants or products that are in solid or liquid form, as these are not considered in the equilibrium constant. If you have any more questions or need additional explanation on your previous questions, please let me know. Best, Niranjana

Input.threadtitle: equilibrium constant for dissociation of N2O4 into NO2?
Input.posts:
I have some questions about the equilibrium constant for the disassociation of dinitrogen tetroxide (colourless gas) into nitrogen dioxide (brown gas). Question 1: Does this equilibrium constant have units? One molecule of dinitrogen tetroxide gives two molecules of nitrogen dioxide, so M (the units in the numerator of the equilibrium constand expression) divided by M^2 (units in the denominator) gives units of M-1. Is that right? However, In one of the video lectures the prof said equilibrium constants do not have units (I read on the Internet a complicated story about 'activities' which I couldn't understand) Question 2: What is the numerical value of the equilibrium constant for this reaction at 25 degrees Celsius? I have searched high and low on the Internet for this figure and cannot find it (in spite of the fact the equilibrium in question is widely discussed on the Internet) Question 3: If you put the dinitrogen tetroxide on the right and the nitrogen dioxide on the left (so reverse the way you write the equation) would the equilibrium constant be the inverse of the answer to question 2? Question 4: Is the equilibrium constant for this reaction different at different pressures? I'm really hoping for an answer from a chemistry expert - not looking to ignite any debate or controversy here. So if anyone out there who knows about chemistry can help me out it would be greatly appreciated.

Hi Peter, my name is Niranjana and I am a teaching assistant for this course. My apologies for the delay in responding to your questions. I have provided responses to your questions below. (1) No, as another student posted as well the equilibrium constant does not have units. The ratio that you use to determine the equilibrium constant is either entirely in units of concentration or pressure, in which case the units cancel once you divide the values. In the type of example that you described where there are an unequal number of reactants and products in a reaction, and therefore in the equilibrium constant expression, the activities help cancel the units so the overall equilibrium constant expression, k, is unit less. Typically, activities are negligible and will not be considered in general chemistry. Activities simply help correct for the dissociation of reactants and products, but you do not need to worry about them for this course. (2) The value of Keq for this reaction is 6.54 × 10−3 at 25 degrees Celsius. (3) Yes, this is correct. When you reverse a reaction, the value of the equilibrium constant will be equal to 1/(Keq for the forward reaction). (4) Although we want to think that any changes to the reaction conditions will change the value of Keq, this is not the case. For example, changes in pressure alter which side of the reaction is favored at equilibrium, but it does not change the value of Keq itself - only changes in temperature will alter the value of Keq. I hope this helps clear up your questions. Also, remember that if you have coefficients in front of your reactants and products, you must raise the concentration or pressure of those reactants to that power when you are calculating the equilibrium constant value. This rule applies to this reaction for example, where the reaction is N2O4 --> 2NO2. So you would divide ([NO2]^2)/(N2O4). Also, be sure to exclude any reactants or products that are in solid or liquid form, as these are not considered in the equilibrium constant. If you have any more questions or need additional explanation on your previous questions, please let me know. Best, Niranjana
